clinical_question: Should patients with RA on DMARDs who are in remission gradually taper off DMARDs, Abruptly withdraw DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD), or continue DMARDS at the same doses?
population: Patients with RA on DMARDs in remission
intervention: Taper off DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD)
comparator: Abruptly withdraw DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD)
outcome: Disease activity (follow up: 9 months; assessed with: ACR 20)

Risk of bias.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious risk of bias. Lack of allocation concealment, incomplete outcome data and selective reporting.

Imprecision.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious imprecision. Confidence interval includes both values suggesting no effect and values suggesting benefit.

Effect.Abbreviations: CI: Confidence interval; RR: Risk ratio; MD: Mean difference; HR: Hazard Ratio

population: Patients with RA on DMARDs in remission

comparator: Abruptly withdraw DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD)
outcome: Disease activity (follow up: 9 months; assessed with: DAS28-ESR (Lower values – > benefit) (MCID -1.17)

Risk of bias.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious risk of bias. Lack of allocation concealment, incomplete outcome data and selective reporting.

population: Patients with RA on DMARDs in remission
intervention: Taper off DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD)
comparator: Abruptly withdraw DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD)
outcome: Remission (follow up: 9 months; assessed with: DAS28ESR < 2.6)

Risk of bias.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious risk of bias. Lack of allocation concealment, incomplete outcome data and selective reporting.

Effect.Abbreviations: CI: Confidence interval; RR: Risk ratio; MD: Mean difference; HR: Hazard Ratio

population: Patients with RA on DMARDs in remission

comparator: Abruptly withdraw DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD)

clinical_question: Should patients with RA on DMARDs who are in remission gradually taper off DMARDs, Abruptly withdraw DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD), or continue DMARDS at the same doses?
population: Patients with RA on DMARDs in remission
intervention: Taper off DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD)
comparator: Abruptly withdraw DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD)
outcome: Radiographic progression (follow up: 9 months; assessed with: mTSS (Lower values – > benefit) (MCID 4.6)

Risk of bias.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious risk of bias. Lack of allocation concealment, incomplete outcome data and selective reporting.

Effect.Abbreviations: CI: Confidence interval; RR: Risk ratio; MD: Mean difference; HR: Hazard Ratio

clinical_question: Should patients with RA on DMARDs who are in remission gradually taper off DMARDs, Abruptly withdraw DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD), or continue DMARDS at the same doses?
population: Patients with RA on DMARDs in remission
intervention: Taper off DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD)
comparator: Abruptly withdraw DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD)
outcome: Quality of Life (follow up: 9 months; assessed with: SF-36 PCS (Higher values – > benefit) (MCID 4.4)

Risk of bias.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious risk of bias. Lack of allocation concealment, incomplete outcome data and selective reporting.

Imprecision.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious imprecision. Confidence interval includes both values suggesting no effect and values suggesting benefit.

Effect.Absolute Effect (95% CI): MD 2.3 higher (0.47 lower to 5.07 higher)(The study PRIZE found that the RR of improvement in SF-36 PCS (≥ 5 change from baseline) was 1.03 (95%CI 0.86 to 1.24), absolute risk increase 23 more per 1000 (95%CI 108 fewer to 185 more).)
Effect.Abbreviations: CI: Confidence interval; RR: Risk ratio; MD: Mean difference; HR: Hazard Ratio

clinical_question: Should patients with RA on DMARDs who are in remission gradually taper off DMARDs, Abruptly withdraw DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD), or continue DMARDS at the same doses?
population: Patients with RA on DMARDs in remission
intervention: Taper off DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD)
comparator: Abruptly withdraw DMARDs (as long as the patient remains on at least one DMARD)
outcome: Quality of Life (follow up: 9 months; assessed with: SF-36 MCS (Higher values – > benefit) (MCID 3.1)

Risk of bias.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious risk of bias. Lack of allocation concealment, incomplete outcome data and selective reporting.

Imprecision.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious imprecision. Confidence interval includes both values suggesting no effect and values suggesting benefit.

Effect.Absolute Effect (95% CI): MD 1.8 higher (0.97 lower to 4.57 higher)(The study PRIZE found that the RR of improvement in SF-36 MCS (≥ 5 change from baseline) was 1.27 (95%CI 0.91 to 1.78), absolute risk increase 125 more per 1000 (95%CI 42 fewer to 360 more).)
Effect.Abbreviations: CI: Confidence interval; RR: Risk ratio; MD: Mean difference; HR: Hazard Ratio
